counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of EU Integration would have supported the same policy objective — protecting retail workers' right to weekly rest — but through standard legislative procedure with a full regulatory impact assessment, structured stakeholder consultation, and a carefully designed exemption framework. Rather than an extraordinary session and constitutional entrenchment, the law should have been adopted through regular parliamentary procedure with committee hearings, followed by implementing regulations that define clear exemptions for tourism municipalities, seasonal periods, and essential services. This approach would achieve the same worker protection while demonstrating the legislative maturity the European Commission expects.
key_changes: Adopt through regular parliamentary procedure with full committee review and public hearings, not an extraordinary session
Commission a regulatory impact assessment before adoption, analyzing effects on retail employment, tourism revenue, SME viability, and consumer access

Define a clear exemption framework in the primary legislation: tourism-designated municipalities (coastal and mountain areas), peak season periods (June-September, December-January), essential retail (pharmacies, fuel stations, airport/port shops), and small family-owned businesses below a defined size threshold
Drop the constitutional amendment in favor of a statutory framework with a mandatory 18-month review clause
Establish compensatory measures for Sunday work where exemptions apply (premium pay of at least 50%, guaranteed alternative rest day) aligned with EU social policy standards
Create a formal consultation body including the Chamber of Commerce, Union of Employers, Confederation of Trade Unions, and consumer associations for future labor legislation
expected_benefits: Full compatibility with EU acquis while demonstrating mature legislative process — directly supporting positive assessments in EC annual progress reports
Protection of Montenegro's tourism competitiveness, which is critical for economic convergence targets under the accession process
Stronger credibility with the European Commission on rule of law and institutional capacity benchmarks under Chapters 23 and 24
Reduced risk of future legal challenges from businesses or the EU side regarding disproportionate restrictions on service provision
A replicable model for future labor market reforms that balances social protection with economic flexibility
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: Highly feasible — the same policy outcome would have been achievable within a standard 60-90 day legislative timeline. The exemption framework could draw directly on existing EU member state models (Germany's Ladenschlussgesetz, Croatia's Zakon o trgovini, Poland's Sunday trading law). The only political cost would have been a modest delay, which is far outweighed by the institutional credibility gained with the European Commission.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Okvir za odmor nedjeljom zasnovan na dokazima s mjerama zaštite turizma
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Ministarstvo evropskih integracija podržalo bi isti politički cilj — zaštitu prava radnika u trgovini na sedmični odmor — ali putem standardne zakonodavne procedure uz potpunu procjenu regulatornog uticaja, strukturisane konsultacije s akterima i pažljivo osmišljen okvir izuzeća. Umjesto vanrednog zasjedanja i ustavnog učvršćivanja, zakon je trebalo donijeti redovnom parlamentarnom procedurom uz sjednice odbora, a potom donijeti provedbene propise koji jasno definišu izuzeća za turistička mjesta, sezonske periode i osnovne usluge. Ovaj pristup bi ostvario istu zaštitu radnika, uz istovremenu demonstraciju zakonodavne zrelosti koju Evropska komisija očekuje.
key_changes_mne: Donijeti zakon redovnom parlamentarnom procedurom uz punu analizu u odborima i javna saslušanja, a ne putem vanrednog zasjedanja
Naručiti procjenu regulatornog uticaja prije donošenja zakona, s analizom efekata na zaposlenost u trgovini, prihode od turizma, održivost malih i srednjih preduzeća i pristup potrošača

Definisati jasan okvir izuzeća u primarnom zakonodavstvu: opštine s turističkim statusom (primorska i planinska područja), periodi glavne sezone (jun–septembar, decembar–januar), osnovna maloprodaja (apoteke, benzinske stanice, prodavnice u aerodromima i lukama) i mala porodična preduzeća ispod definisanog praga veličine
Odustati od ustavnih izmjena u korist zakonskog okvira s obaveznom klauzulom o preispitivanju nakon 18 mjeseci
Uspostaviti kompenzatorne mjere za rad nedjeljom u slučajevima primjene izuzeća (uvećana naknada od najmanje 50%, zagarantovan alternativni dan odmora) usklađene sa standardima EU socijalne politike
Obrazovati formalno tijelo za konsultacije koje uključuje Privrednu komoru, Uniju poslodavaca, Savez sindikata i udruženja potrošača za buduće radno zakonodavstvo
expected_benefits_mne: Potpuna usklađenost sa pravnom tekovinom EU uz demonstraciju zrelog zakonodavnog procesa — direktna podrška pozitivnim ocjenama u godišnjim izvještajima Evropske komisije o napretku
Zaštita turističke konkurentnosti Crne Gore, koja je ključna za ciljeve ekonomske konvergencije u okviru pristupnog procesa
Jači kredibilitet pred Evropskom komisijom u pogledu vladavine prava i institucionalnih kapaciteta prema mjerilima poglavlja 23 i 24
Smanjen rizik od budućih pravnih sporova od strane privrednika ili EU u vezi s nesrazmjernim ograničenjima pružanja usluga
Model koji se može primjenjivati u budućim reformama tržišta rada, koji usklađuje socijalnu zaštitu s ekonomskom fleksibilnošću
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoko izvodljivo — isti politički ishod bio bi ostvariv u okviru standardnog zakonodavnog roka od 60 do 90 dana. Okvir izuzeća mogao bi se neposredno oslanjati na postojeće modele država članica EU (njemački Ladenschlussgesetz, hrvatski Zakon o trgovini, poljski zakon o nedjeljnoj trgovini). Jedini politički trošak bio bi skromno odlaganje, koje je daleko nadmašeno institucionalnim kredibilitetom stečenim pred Evropskom komisijom.

assessments.summary_mne: Zakon o nedeljnom odmoru za radnike u maloprodaji uglavnom je usklađen s pravom EU, s obzirom na to da Direktiva EU o radnom vremenu (2003/88/EZ) propisuje minimalni sedmični odmor od 24 uzastopna sata, ali ne određuje koji dan mora biti određen kao dan odmora. Nekoliko država članica EU zadržava slična ograničenja nedeljne trgovine (Njemačka, Austrija, Poljska, dijelovi Francuske). Zakon ne predstavlja direktnu prepreku pristupanju EU, međutim, način donošenja — putem vanrednog zasjedanja parlamenta, jednoglasnim glasanjem bez smislene rasprave, te istovremenim nastojanjem da se ugradi u Ustav — izaziva proceduralne zabrinutosti u pogledu kvaliteta regulacije i zrelosti crnogorskog zakonodavnog procesa, što je relevantno za Poglavlje 23 (Pravosuđe i osnovna prava) i Poglavlje 3 (Pravo poslovnog nastana i sloboda pružanja usluga).
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Zakon o nedeljnom odmoru nije nespojiv s pravnim tekovinama EU, s obzirom na to da Direktiva o radnom vremenu državama članicama ostavlja diskreciono pravo u pogledu uređivanja sedmičnog odmora, a mnoge zemlje EU ograničavaju nedeljnu trgovinu. Međutim, ubrzana procedura vanrednog zasjedanja i prijedlog za uzdizanje ovog pitanja na ustavni nivo nesrazmjerni su i izazivaju zabrinutost u pogledu kvaliteta zakonodavstva — što je ponavljajuća kritika u izvještajima Evropske komisije o napretku. Ministarstvo preporučuje da buduće reforme tržišta rada slijede standardne zakonodavne procedure uz odgovarajuće procjene uticaja i konsultacije s interesnim stranama.
key_concerns_mne: Ubrzana zakonodavna procedura putem vanrednog zasjedanja (manje od 3 sedmice od prijedloga do usvajanja) narušava standarde kvaliteta zakonodavstva koji se prate u okviru Poglavlja 23
Odsustvo objavljene procjene regulatornog uticaja, što je standardni zahtjev EU za zakonodavne prijedloge i ponavljajuća kritika u izvještajima EK o napretku
Nedovoljno jasno definisane izuzetke — uticaj zakona na crnogorsku ekonomiju koja je zavisna od turizma (turizam čini više od 20% BDP-a) zahtijeva pažljivo definisane sektorski specifične izuzetke
Predloženi ustavni amandman je nesrazmjeran i mogao bi umanjiti zakonodavnu fleksibilnost potrebnu za usklađivanje s budućim razvojem pravnih tekovina EU
Nema dokaza o strukturisanim konsultacijama s interesnim stranama — udruženjima poslodavaca, MSP-ovima, sindikatima ili potrošačkim grupama — kako to nalažu principi EU o boljoj regulaciji
Potencijalno trenje s Poglavljem 3 (Sloboda pružanja usluga) ukoliko izuzeci za strane pružaoce usluga i prekogranični promet ne budu adekvatno regulisani
recommendations_mne: Sprovesti i objaviti retroaktivnu procjenu regulatornog uticaja (RIA) prije stupanja zakona na snagu, uključujući ekonomsko modelovanje efekata na sektore turizma i maloprodaje

Usvojiti detaljne provedbene propise koji preciziraju jasne i srazmjerne izuzetke za turističke zone, prigranična područja, sezonske djelatnosti, apoteke, benzinske stanice i osnovne usluge — po uzoru na hrvatska i njemačka iskustva
Odustati od prijedloga ustavnog amandmana ili ga odložiti — nedjeljna zabrana rada bolje se reguliše na zakonodavnom nivou radi očuvanja fleksibilnosti za buduće usklađivanje s pravnim tekovinama EU
Uspostaviti formalni mehanizam konsultacija s interesnim stranama za buduće zakonodavstvo iz oblasti tržišta rada, u skladu sa standardima EU o boljoj regulaciji i zahtjevima Poglavlja 19

Zatražiti tehničku recenziju od strane Generalnog direktorata EK za zapošljavanje (DG EMPL) ili SIGME (Podrška poboljšanju upravljanja i menadžmenta) radi poređenja zakona s praksama država članica EU
Uključiti klauzulu o prestanku važenja ili preispitivanju (npr. obavezno preispitivanje nakon 18 mjeseci) radi procjene ekonomskog uticaja i prilagođavanja izuzetaka na osnovu dokaza

assessments.summary: The Sunday Rest Law for retail workers, while addressing legitimate labor rights concerns, represents a blunt regulatory intervention that will disproportionately harm Montenegro's tourism-dependent economy, reduce SME competitiveness, and send a concerning signal to foreign investors. The unanimous passage without apparent economic impact assessment, the rushed extraordinary session procedure, and the proposed constitutional entrenchment of what should be a flexible labor policy all point to a decision driven primarily by political signaling rather than sound economic policymaking.
assessments.executive_summary: This law will materially damage Montenegro's retail sector and tourism competitiveness — sectors that together account for a dominant share of GDP and employment. The Ministry of Economy's top concern is the absence of exemptions for tourism zones and seasonal retail, and the constitutional amendment proposal which would make future economic adjustment nearly impossible. We recommend the law be amended before gazette publication to include geographic and seasonal exemptions.
assessments.reasoning:
Montenegro is a small, open, services-driven economy where tourism contributes approximately 25% of GDP directly and significantly more indirectly. The retail sector is deeply intertwined with tourism — coastal towns like Budva, Kotor, Herceg Novi, and Tivat see peak commercial activity on weekends, including Sundays, particularly during the May-October season when the country receives the vast majority of its international visitors. A blanket Sunday closure mandate for retail will directly reduce revenue opportunities during the most commercially productive days of the week.

From a labor market perspective, the retail sector is one of Montenegro's largest employers, particularly for women, young workers, and those with lower formal qualifications. While the intention to protect workers' rest days is commendable and aligned with certain EU member state practices, the implementation matters enormously. Countries like Germany and Austria that maintain Sunday trading restrictions have much larger, more diversified economies and well-developed compensatory mechanisms (higher wages, shift premiums, strong collective bargaining). Montenegro has none of these structural supports in place. The likely immediate labor market effect is not better working conditions but rather reduced hours, lower total compensation for hourly workers, and potential job losses — particularly in SMEs that operate on thin margins and depend on Sunday revenue.

The SME impact is especially concerning. Montenegro's retail landscape is dominated by small and micro enterprises. Large chains can absorb a one-seventh revenue reduction more easily through operational efficiencies and omnichannel strategies. Small shop owners — particularly family-run businesses in tourist areas — will face an existential threat. Many of these businesses earn a disproportionate share of weekly revenue on Sundays. There was no apparent consultation with the Chamber of Economy, the Employers' Federation, or SME associations before this extraordinary session.

For foreign direct investment, the signal is troubling on two levels. First, investors in retail, hospitality-adjacent commerce, and mixed-use real estate developments (such as Porto Montenegro or Lustica Bay) will face operational constraints that reduce projected returns. Second, and more importantly, the process — an extraordinary parliamentary session with unanimous passage and no visible impact assessment — raises governance and regulatory predictability concerns. FDI thrives on stable, predictable regulatory environments. The additional proposal to constitutionalize this right elevates the concern dramatically: constitutional provisions are extraordinarily difficult to amend, meaning any future government that recognizes the economic damage will face near-impossible barriers to correction.

Comparing with EU practice: while several EU member states restrict Sunday trading, none have constitutionalized such restrictions, and most include extensive exemptions for tourism areas, transport hubs, seasonal periods, and small businesses. Croatia, a direct competitor and neighbor, allows Sunday trading in tourist zones. If Montenegro closes while Croatian coastal towns remain open, cross-border shopping leakage will increase, particularly in the Bay of Kotor area near Dubrovnik.

The energy and industrial policy dimensions are minimal, though the reduction in commercial operating hours will marginally reduce energy consumption — a negligible benefit that does not offset the economic costs.

The procedural dimension cannot be ignored. An extraordinary session called on January 28 with a vote on February 16 — less than three weeks — for a law affecting tens of thousands of workers and thousands of businesses, with no published regulatory impact assessment, no public consultation period, and no transition period, is not consistent with good regulatory practice or Montenegro's EU accession commitments under Chapter 3 (Right of Establishment and Freedom to Provide Services) and Chapter 8 (Competition Policy).
key_concerns: No exemptions for tourism-dependent municipalities or seasonal retail operations, directly threatening Montenegro's core economic sector
Disproportionate impact on SMEs and micro-enterprises that depend on Sunday revenue and cannot absorb a ~14% reduction in trading days
No regulatory impact assessment or economic analysis was published before the extraordinary session vote
The proposed constitutional amendment would make future economic correction virtually impossible, locking in an inflexible policy
Reduced competitiveness vis-à-vis Croatia and other regional tourism destinations that allow Sunday trading
Risk of increased informal economy activity as businesses attempt to circumvent restrictions through unofficial Sunday operations
Negative signal to foreign investors regarding regulatory predictability and evidence-based policymaking
No transition period for businesses to adjust operations, staffing models, and financial planning
Potential reduction in total worker compensation (fewer hours) rather than improved working conditions, absent compensatory wage mechanisms
recommendations: Introduce geographic exemptions for municipalities with significant tourism activity (at minimum: coastal municipalities and Žabljak, Kolašin, Cetinje) allowing Sunday retail operations during tourist season (May-October)
Exempt micro and small enterprises (under 10 employees) from the Sunday closure requirement, consistent with EU practice in countries like Germany
Mandate a 6-month transition period before enforcement to allow businesses to adjust operations and renegotiate employment contracts
Commission and publish a full regulatory impact assessment through the Ministry of Economy before any constitutional amendment is considered
Introduce mandatory Sunday premium pay (e.g., 150% of regular rate) as an alternative to outright closure, giving workers economic benefit while preserving business viability
Establish a monitoring mechanism to track the law's impact on retail employment, SME revenue, tourism spending, and informal economy indicators over the first 12 months
Strongly oppose the constitutional amendment proposal — labor flexibility should remain within ordinary legislative competence
Consult with the Chamber of Economy, Union of Employers, and relevant trade unions to develop implementing regulations that balance worker protection with economic reality

counter_proposal.title: Flexible Sunday Rest with Tourism and SME Safeguards
counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of Economy would replace the blanket Sunday closure with a tiered system: mandatory Sunday rest applies to large retail chains (50+ employees) year-round nationwide, while SMEs and all retailers in designated tourism zones receive seasonal exemptions. Workers choosing to work Sundays would receive a 50% wage premium by law. A voluntary Sunday closure incentive program would provide tax relief to businesses that choose to close. The constitutional amendment would be abandoned entirely in favor of keeping this within ordinary legislation subject to periodic review.
key_changes: Apply mandatory Sunday closure only to large retail operations (50+ employees) outside tourism zones
Designate tourism zones (coastal municipalities, ski resorts, UNESCO heritage areas) exempt from May through October
Introduce mandatory 50% Sunday wage premium for all retail workers working on Sundays
Create a voluntary closure incentive: businesses that voluntarily close Sundays receive a 5% reduction in local surtax
Mandate a 6-month implementation timeline with a 12-month review clause
Abandon the constitutional amendment proposal entirely
expected_benefits: Preserves tourism competitiveness and Sunday retail revenue estimated at 12-15% of weekly retail turnover
Protects SMEs from disproportionate revenue loss while still improving working conditions through wage premiums
Maintains FDI attractiveness by demonstrating evidence-based, proportionate regulation
Achieves the core worker protection goal through economic incentives rather than blanket prohibition
Retains legislative flexibility for future adjustment as Montenegro's economy evolves toward EU accession
Reduces risk of informal economy expansion by keeping legal Sunday trading channels open
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility: High. The tiered approach mirrors proven models in Germany, Austria, and Italy. The wage premium mechanism is straightforward to implement through existing labor inspection infrastructure. Tourism zone designation can leverage existing municipal classification systems. The main political obstacle is that the current law passed unanimously, suggesting strong cross-party consensus — but economic evidence and stakeholder pressure from SMEs and tourism operators could build a coalition for amendment within 3-6 months.
counter_proposal.title_mne: Fleksibilno nedjeljno odmiranje uz zaštitu turizma i malih i srednjih preduzeća
counter_proposal.summary_mne: Ministarstvo ekonomije bi zamijenilo opštu zabranu rada nedjeljom višeslojnim sistemom: obavezno nedjeljno odmiranje primjenjuje se na velike maloprodajne lance (50+ zaposlenih) tokom cijele godine na teritoriji čitave države, dok mala i srednja preduzeća i svi trgovci u određenim turističkim zonama dobijaju sezonske izuzetke. Radnici koji se odluče za rad nedjeljom imali bi zakonsko pravo na uvećanu zaradu od 50%. Program dobrovoljnog podsticaja za zatvaranje nedjeljom predviđao bi poreske olakšice za preduzeća koja se odluče na prekid rada. Prijedlog ustavnih izmjena bio bi u potpunosti napušten u korist zadržavanja ove materije u okviru redovnog zakonodavstva podložnog periodičnoj reviziji.
key_changes_mne: Primijeniti obavezno nedjeljno zatvaranje isključivo na velike maloprodajne objekte (50+ zaposlenih) izvan turističkih zona
Odrediti turističke zone (primorske opštine, skijališta, lokaliteti pod zaštitom UNESCO-a) koje su izuzete od primjene od maja do oktobra
Uvesti obavezni nedjeljni dodatak na zaradu od 50% za sve maloprodajne radnike koji rade nedjeljom
Uspostaviti podsticaj za dobrovoljno zatvaranje: preduzeća koja dobrovoljno ne rade nedjeljom ostvaruju pravo na smanjenje lokalnog prireza od 5%
Propisati rok za implementaciju od 6 mjeseci uz klauzulu o preispitivanju nakon 12 mjeseci
U potpunosti napustiti prijedlog ustavnih izmjena
expected_benefits_mne: Čuva konkurentnost turizma i nedjeljni maloprodajni prihod koji se procjenjuje na 12–15% sedmičnog maloprodajnog prometa
Štiti mala i srednja preduzeća od nesrazmjernog gubitka prihoda, istovremeno unapređujući radne uslove putem uvećane zarade
Održava atraktivnost za strana direktna ulaganja demonstriranjem regulacije zasnovane na dokazima i srazmjerne po obimu
Postiže suštinski cilj zaštite radnika putem ekonomskih podsticaja, umjesto opšte zabrane
Zadržava zakonodavnu fleksibilnost za buduća prilagođavanja kako crnogorska ekonomija evoluira u smjeru pristupanja EU
Smanjuje rizik od širenja sive ekonomije održavanjem otvorenih zakonskih kanala za nedjeljnu trgovinu
counter_proposal.estimated_feasibility_mne: Visoka. Višeslojni pristup odražava provjerene modele primijenjene u Njemačkoj, Austriji i Italiji. Mehanizam uvećane zarade je jednostavan za primjenu putem postojeće infrastrukture inspekcije rada. Određivanje turističkih zona može se osloniti na postojeće sisteme opštinske klasifikacije. Glavna politička prepreka leži u tome što je važeći zakon usvojen jednoglasno, što upućuje na snažan međustranački konsenzus — međutim, ekonomski argumenti i pritisak zainteresovanih strana iz reda malih i srednjih preduzeća i turističkih operatera mogli bi izgraditi koaliciju za izmjenu zakona u roku od 3 do 6 mjeseci.

assessments.summary_mne: Zakon o nedjelji kao danu odmora za radnike u trgovini, iako se bavi legitimnim zabrinutostima u oblasti radnih prava, predstavlja grubu regulatornu intervenciju koja će nesrazmjerno naškoditi crnogorskoj ekonomiji ovisnoj o turizmu, smanjiti konkurentnost malih i srednjih preduzeća i poslati zabrinjavajući signal stranim investitorima. Jednoglasno usvajanje bez vidljive procjene ekonomskog uticaja, ubrzana procedura vanrednog zasjedanja i predloženo ustavno učvršćivanje onoga što bi trebalo biti fleksibilna radna politika — sve to ukazuje na odluku vođenu prije svega političkim signaliziranjem nego zdravim ekonomskim kreiranjem politika.
assessments.executive_summary_mne: Ovaj zakon će materijalno oštetiti crnogorski maloprodajni sektor i turističku konkurentnost — sektore koji zajedno čine dominantni udio u BDP-u i zaposlenosti. Najveća zabrinutost Ministarstva ekonomije tiče se izostanka izuzetaka za turističke zone i sezonsku trgovinu, kao i prijedloga ustavnog amandmana koji bi buduće ekonomske prilagodbe učinio gotovo nemogućim. Preporučujemo da se zakon izmijeni prije objavljivanja u Službenom listu, kako bi se uveli geografski i sezonski izuzeci.
key_concerns_mne: Nema izuzetaka za opštine ovisne o turizmu niti za sezonske trgovinske djelatnosti, što direktno ugrožava ključni ekonomski sektor Crne Gore
Nesrazmjeran uticaj na mala i srednja preduzeća i mikro-preduzeća koja zavise od nedeljnih prihoda i ne mogu apsorbovati smanjenje trgovačkih dana od oko 14%
Nije objavljena procjena regulatornog uticaja niti ekonomska analiza prije glasanja na vanrednom zasjedanju
Predloženi ustavni amandman učiniće buduće ekonomske korekcije gotovo nemogućim, fiksiranjem nefleksibilne politike
Smanjena konkurentnost u odnosu na Hrvatsku i druga regionalna turistička odredišta koja dozvoljavaju trgovinu nedjeljom
Rizik od porasta sive ekonomije, jer će preduzeća pokušavati da zaobiđu ograničenja neslužbenim nedjeljnim radom
Negativan signal stranim investitorima u pogledu predvidivosti regulatornog okvira i donošenja politika zasnovanih na dokazima
Ne postoji prelazni period koji bi preduzećima omogućio prilagođavanje poslovanja, modela zapošljavanja i finansijskog planiranja
Potencijalno smanjenje ukupnih primanja radnika (manji broj radnih sati) umjesto poboljšanja uslova rada, bez kompenzatornih mehanizama zarada
recommendations_mne: Uvesti geografske izuzetke za opštine sa značajnom turističkom djelatnošću (kao minimum: primorske opštine i Žabljak, Kolašin, Cetinje) koji će dozvoliti nedjeljnu trgovinu tokom turističke sezone (maj–oktobar)
Izuzeti mikro i mala preduzeća (ispod 10 zaposlenih) od obaveze nedjeljnog zatvaranja, u skladu sa praksom EU u zemljama poput Njemačke
Utvrditi obavezni prelazni period od 6 mjeseci prije početka primjene, kako bi preduzeća mogla prilagoditi poslovanje i pregovarati o ugovorima o radu
Naložiti izradu i objavljivanje potpune procjene regulatornog uticaja od strane Ministarstva ekonomije prije razmatranja bilo kakvog ustavnog amandmana
Uvesti obavezan uvećani nedeljni koeficijent zarade (npr. 150% redovne stope) kao alternativu potpunom zatvaranju, čime se radnicima pruža ekonomska korist uz očuvanje poslovne održivosti
Uspostaviti mehanizam praćenja kako bi se mjerio uticaj zakona na zaposlenost u trgovini, prihode malih i srednjih preduzeća, turističku potrošnju i pokazatelje sive ekonomije tokom prvih 12 mjeseci
Odlučno se suprotstaviti prijedlogu ustavnog amandmana — fleksibilnost radnog zakonodavstva treba ostati u okviru redovne zakonodavne nadležnosti
Konsultovati Privrednu komoru, Uniju poslodavaca i relevantne sindikate radi izrade provedbenih propisa koji balansiraju zaštitu radnika i ekonomsku stvarnost

assessments.summary: While the Ministry of Tourism recognizes the legitimate social objective of protecting retail workers' rights to rest, a blanket Sunday closure law for retail without explicit, well-defined tourism exemptions poses a serious operational threat to Montenegro's tourism sector, which generates approximately 40% of GDP and is overwhelmingly concentrated in the May–October season. Sunday is one of the highest-revenue days for coastal and national park destinations, and the law as passed risks degrading visitor experience, damaging Montenegro's competitiveness against Croatia, Albania, and Greece, and undermining the livelihoods of seasonal workers who depend on peak-period earnings.
assessments.executive_summary: The Sunday rest law, while socially well-intentioned, threatens to significantly disrupt Montenegro's tourism-dependent economy by closing retail on one of the busiest visitor days. The absence of a clear, automatic tourism-sector exemption is the core deficiency. The Ministry recommends immediate adoption of a seasonal exemption framework for tourism zones and a compensatory rest model for affected workers.
assessments.reasoning:
Montenegro's tourism model is fundamentally incompatible with a rigid Sunday retail closure. Several dimensions of impact must be considered:

**1. Revenue and Visitor Experience Impact.** Sunday is consistently among the top two spending days for tourists across Budva, Kotor, Tivat, Herceg Novi, and Ulcinj. Cruise ship arrivals in Kotor — which can bring 5,000–10,000 visitors in a single day — frequently fall on Sundays. These visitors have limited time ashore (typically 6–8 hours) and expect to shop, dine, and engage with local commerce. A closed retail environment on Sundays would directly translate to lost revenue for local businesses and a diminished visitor experience, with reputational consequences amplified through online reviews and cruise line feedback.

**2. Seasonal Employment and Labour Dynamics.** Approximately 25,000–30,000 seasonal workers depend on the May–October tourism window for the bulk of their annual income. Many of these workers are employed in retail, souvenir shops, and market stalls in coastal towns. A Sunday closure reduces their available earning days by roughly 14% during the season. While the intent is to protect workers, the effect on seasonal employees — who are often on fixed-term contracts and paid hourly or daily — may be the opposite: reduced income without meaningful improvement in working conditions. The law appears designed with year-round, urban retail workers in mind, not the seasonal tourism workforce.

**3. Competitiveness Against Regional Rivals.** Croatia, Greece, and Albania — Montenegro's direct competitors — all maintain flexible Sunday trading regimes in tourist zones during high season. Croatia's Trade Act explicitly exempts municipalities with significant tourism activity. If Montenegro closes on Sundays while Dubrovnik, Saranda, and Corfu remain open, tourists and tour operators will adjust itineraries accordingly. This is especially damaging for day-trip and cruise traffic, which is highly price- and convenience-elastic.

**4. National Park and Ecotourism.** Durmitor, Biogradska Gora, Skadar Lake, Prokletije, and Lovćen increasingly attract weekend visitors — both domestic and international. Sunday closures of retail points within or adjacent to park areas (visitor centres, souvenir shops, local produce stalls) would undermine the agritourism and rural development strategies the Ministry has been promoting, particularly in northern Montenegro where economic alternatives are scarce.

**5. Constitutional Enshrinement Risk.** President Milatović's proposal to constitutionally enshrine Sunday rest is particularly alarming from a tourism policy perspective. Constitutional provisions are extremely difficult to amend or create exceptions to. If Sunday rest becomes a constitutional right without explicit carve-outs for tourism, future flexibility to adapt to market conditions, EU accession requirements, or seasonal demands would be severely constrained. EU member states generally handle Sunday trading through ordinary legislation precisely to maintain policy flexibility.

**6. EU Alignment.** The EU does not mandate Sunday closures; this is left to member states. However, the EU Services Directive and internal market principles generally discourage blanket restrictions on commercial activity that disproportionately affect cross-border service provision, including tourism. As Montenegro progresses through EU accession (Chapters 3 and 19 are relevant), rigid Sunday closure rules without tourism exemptions could be flagged as a barrier to services liberalisation.

**7. The Law's Silence on Exemptions.** The most critical deficiency is what the law does not say. The text as reported provides for a blanket non-working Sunday for retail employees. While the President's constitutional proposal mentions 'possible legal exceptions in certain sectors necessary to protect public interest,' the law itself — which takes immediate effect — does not appear to contain a tourism exemption mechanism. This creates immediate legal uncertainty for thousands of tourism-facing retail businesses ahead of the 2026 season, which begins in approximately 10 weeks.

counter_proposal.title: Seasonal Tourism Zone Exemption with Worker Protection Framework
counter_proposal.summary: The Ministry of Tourism would propose retaining the Sunday rest principle for year-round, non-tourism retail while establishing a clearly defined exemption regime for tourism-facing retail in designated coastal and national park municipalities during the official tourism season. Workers in exempted zones would receive mandatory compensatory rest days and a Sunday wage premium, achieving both economic and social objectives.
key_changes: Amend the law to include an explicit Article authorising the Government to designate Tourism Activity Zones where Sunday retail trading is permitted from May 1 to October 31
Mandate that workers in exempted zones receive one compensatory rest day per week and a minimum 50% wage premium for Sunday work
Require municipal tourism boards to apply for zone designation annually, ensuring local input and accountability
Exclude the tourism sector from any constitutional Sunday rest provision, preserving legislative flexibility
Establish a joint Ministry of Tourism–Ministry of Labour working group to monitor seasonal worker conditions under the new framework

Maintains Montenegro's competitiveness with Croatia and regional rivals for cruise and weekend tourism

Provides legal certainty for tourism businesses ahead of the 2026 season

The political will exists — the unanimous vote shows consensus on worker protection, and framing the exemption as complementary rather than contradictory to that goal is achievable.

blind_spots: Constitutional Court previously struck down a similar Sunday closure provision as unconstitutional — re-enacting it without curing the constitutional defects is a direct legislative override of judicial review and a serious rule-of-law violation

No ministry explicitly identified PES's political motivation for calling an extraordinary session on a populist labor issue — this has the hallmarks of electoral positioning, not evidence-based policymaking

No analysis of the gender-differentiated economic impact: retail is disproportionately female-employing, and reduced hours/income will hit women workers hardest, contradicting the law's stated social protection goals

The 62-0 unanimity is treated as a positive signal by some ministries, but in a functional democracy it is a red flag — it suggests opposition parties were co-opted or afraid to oppose a popular measure, not that the law was genuinely uncontroversial

No ministry modeled the substitution effect: will consumers shift spending to online retailers (which are exempt from Sunday closures), benefiting foreign e-commerce platforms at the expense of domestic brick-and-mortar?

Zero analysis of the law's interaction with Montenegro's informal economy — estimated at 25-30% of GDP — where Sunday closures of formal retail will simply redirect consumer spending to unregulated sellers

No ministry addressed the temporal absurdity: the law takes immediate effect upon gazette publication with no transition period, meaning businesses get zero time to adjust staffing, contracts, or operations

The proposed constitutional amendment by President Milatović was treated as a separate concern rather than what it is: a coordinated political escalation that signals the executive and legislature are aligned in overriding the judiciary
No ministry analyzed worker preferences — many retail employees, particularly students and seasonal workers, actively want Sunday shifts for the premium pay or schedule flexibility
critic_report.overall_analysis:
This decision is a textbook case of populist legislating dressed up as worker protection. The core problem is not the policy goal — giving retail workers a day of rest is a legitimate aim shared by many EU member states. The problems are threefold: process, substance, and constitutional integrity.

**Process failure.** A law affecting tens of thousands of workers and thousands of businesses was rammed through an extraordinary parliamentary session in under three weeks, with no regulatory impact assessment, no stakeholder consultation, no transition period, and no fiscal analysis. The 62-0 vote is not consensus — it is the absence of scrutiny. Every ministry that assessed this law noted the procedural deficiencies, which is damning.

**Substantive failure.** The law is a blunt instrument applied to a nuanced problem. Montenegro is not Germany or Austria — it is a micro-economy of 620,000 people where tourism generates 25-40% of GDP and where the 2026 summer season starts in 10 weeks. Passing a blanket Sunday retail closure with no tourism exemption, no seasonal carve-out, no small-business threshold, and no pharmacy duty-roster requirement is policy malpractice. Croatia, the nearest EU comparator, learned through painful experience that Sunday trading restrictions require calibrated exemptions for tourist zones, small stores, and essential services. Montenegro skipped the learning and went straight to the mistake.

**Constitutional crisis.** The most alarming dimension — largely underweighted by the ministry assessments — is that Montenegro's Constitutional Court had previously struck down a nearly identical Sunday closure provision as unconstitutional, finding it violated entrepreneurial freedom and equal treatment principles. Parliament's response was to re-enact essentially the same provision, and the President's response was to propose constitutionally enshrining it to override the Court entirely. This is not worker protection — this is a coordinated assault on judicial independence. In any EU accession country, legislative override of Constitutional Court rulings is a Chapter 23 red flag of the highest order. The European Commission will notice.

**Assessment quality.** The ministry assessments are generally competent and substantive — significantly better than rubber-stamping. The Ministries of Finance, Economy, Tourism, and Justice all raised serious, well-reasoned objections. The Ministry of Justice in particular identified the rule-of-law concerns clearly. The Health Ministry raised the critical pharmacy access gap. The weaker assessments came from Environment and Interior, which stretched to find relevance but added little. The Education Ministry's assessment was reasonable but somewhat tangential. Overall, the ministries did their analytical jobs — the problem is that the parliament clearly ignored all of it.

**Who benefits?** PES called this extraordinary session. The political calculus is transparent: retail workers are a large, sympathetic voting bloc, Sunday rest is emotionally resonant, and no opposition MP wants to be seen voting against workers' weekends. This was a zero-cost popularity play for PES — zero cost politically, that is. The economic and institutional costs will be borne by small business owners, seasonal workers who lose Sunday income, tourists who find shuttered shops, and Montenegro's constitutional order.

**Bottom line.** The right to weekly rest is a legitimate policy goal that Montenegro should pursue — through ordinary legislative procedure, with a proper impact assessment, stakeholder consultation, tourism exemptions, a transition period, and in compliance with its own Constitutional Court's rulings. What happened instead was a political stunt that undermines the rule of law, threatens the tourism economy, and will almost certainly face another constitutional challenge. Montenegro deserves better governance than this.
critic_report.headline: Parliament Defies Its Own Courts to Score Political Points with Sunday Shopping Ban
critic_report.headline_mne: Parlament prkosi sopstvenim sudovima radi jeftinih političkih poena zabranom rada nedjeljom
critic_report.overall_analysis_mne:
Ova odluka je školski primjer populističkog zakonodavstva presvučenog u radničku zaštitu. Suštinski problem nije politički cilj — davanje radnicima u maloprodaji dana odmora legitiman je cilj koji dijele mnoge države članice EU. Problemi su trostruki: postupak, sadržaj i ustavni integritet.

**Procesni propust.** Zakon koji pogađa desetine hiljada radnika i hiljade preduzeća provučen je kroz vanrednu sjednicu parlamenta za manje od tri sedmice, bez procjene regulatornog uticaja, bez konsultacija s akterima, bez prijelaznog perioda i bez fiskalne analize. Glasanje 62-0 nije konsenzus — to je odsustvo nadzora. Svako ministarstvo koje je razmatralo ovaj zakon ukazalo je na proceduralne nedostatke, što je porazno.

**Suštinski propust.** Zakon je tupo oruđe primijenjeno na slojevit problem. Crna Gora nije Njemačka ni Austrija — to je mikroekonomija od 620.000 stanovnika u kojoj turizam generiše 25–40% BDP-a, a ljetnja sezona 2026. počinje za 10 sedmica. Donošenje sveobuhvatne zabrane rada maloprodaje nedjeljom bez izuzetka za turizam, bez sezonskih odredbi, bez praga za mala preduzeća i bez zahtjeva za dežurstvo apoteka predstavlja političku malpraksu. Hrvatska, najbliži uporedni primjer iz EU, kroz bolno iskustvo naučila je da ograničenja nedeljne trgovine zahtijevaju pažljivo kalibrisane izuzetke za turističke zone, male prodavnice i ključne usluge. Crna Gora je preskočila učenje i direktno napravila grešku.

**Ustavna kriza.** Najalarmantnija dimenzija — koju su ministarstva u velikoj mjeri potcijenila — jeste da je Ustavni sud Crne Gore ranije ukinuo gotovo identičnu odredbu o nedeljnom zatvaranju kao neustavnu, utvrdivši da krši slobodu preduzetništva i načelo jednakog tretmana. Odgovor Parlamenta bio je da suštinski istu odredbu ponovo usvoji, a odgovor predsjednika bio je prijedlog da se ona ugradi u Ustav kako bi se Sud u potpunosti zaobišao. Ovo nije zaštita radnika — ovo je koordinisani napad na nezavisnost pravosuđa. U svakoj zemlji kandidatu za EU, zakonodavno poništavanje odluka Ustavnog suda predstavlja crvenu zastavicu najvišeg reda u okviru Poglavlja 23. Evropska komisija će to primijetiti.

**Kvalitet procjena.** Ministarstvene procjene su općenito kompetentne i suštinski utemeljene — znatno bolje od pukog odobravanja. Ministarstva finansija, ekonomije, turizma i pravde iznijela su ozbiljne i dobro obrazložene primjedbe. Ministarstvo pravde posebno je jasno identifikovalo zabrinutosti vezane za vladavinu prava. Ministarstvo zdravlja ukazalo je na kritičan problem dostupnosti apoteka. Slabije procjene dolaze od Ministarstva ekologije i Ministarstva unutrašnjih poslova, koja su se trudila pronaći relevantnost, ali su malo doprinijela. Procjena Ministarstva prosvjete bila je razumna, ali donekle sporedna. Ukupno gledano, ministarstva su obavila svoj analitički posao — problem je što ih je parlament očigledno ignorisao.

**Ko ima koristi?** PES je sazvao ovu vanrednu sjednicu. Politički kalkul je transparentan: radnici u maloprodaji su brojna i simpatična glasačka baza, nedeljni odmor emocionalno odzvanja, a nijedan poslanik opozicije ne želi biti viđen kako glasa protiv vikenda radnika. Ovo je bila popularizatorska igra bez ikakve cijene za PES — politički bez cijene, to jest. Ekonomske i institucionalne troškove snosiće vlasnici malih preduzeća, sezonski radnici koji gube nedeljnu zaradu, turisti koji nailaze na zatvorene prodavnice, i ustavni poredak Crne Gore.

**Zaključak.** Pravo na sedmični odmor legitiman je politički cilj koji Crna Gora treba da ostvaruje — kroz redovnu zakonodavnu proceduru, uz valjanu procjenu uticaja, konsultacije s akterima, izuzetke za turizam, prijelazni period i u skladu s odlukama sopstvenog Ustavnog suda. Umjesto toga, desio se politički trik koji podriva vladavinu prava, prijeti turističkoj ekonomiji i gotovo sigurno će se suočiti s novim ustavnim osporavanjem. Crna Gora zaslužuje bolju vlast od ove.
blind_spots_mne: Ustavni sud je ranije ukinuo sličnu odredbu o nedeljnom zatvaranju kao neustavnu — njeno ponovno usvajanje bez otklanjanja ustavnih nedostataka predstavlja direktno zakonodavno poništavanje sudske kontrole i ozbiljno kršenje vladavine prava

Nijedno ministarstvo nije eksplicitno identifikovalo političku motivaciju PES-a za sazivanje vanredne sjednice o populističkom radnom pitanju — ovo nosi sve odlike izbornog pozicioniranja, a ne politike zasnovane na dokazima

Nema analize ekonomskog uticaja po rodnoj osnovi: maloprodaja pretežno zapošljava žene, a smanjenje radnih sati i prihoda najtežje će pogoditi radnice, što je u suprotnosti s deklarisanim ciljevima socijalne zaštite zakona

Jednoglasnost 62-0 neka ministarstva tretiraju kao pozitivan signal, ali u funkcionalnoj demokratiji ona je crvena zastavica — sugeriše da su opozicione stranke kooptirane ili uplašene da se suprotstave popularnoj mjeri, a ne da je zakon bio zaista nekontroverzan

Nijedno ministarstvo nije modeliralo efekat supstitucije: hoće li potrošači preseliti potrošnju na online maloprodavce (koji su izuzeti od nedeljnog zatvaranja), koristivši stranim e-commerce platformama na štetu domaće fizičke prodaje

Nula analize interakcije zakona s crnogorskom sivom ekonomijom — procijenjenom na 25–30% BDP-a — gdje će nedeljno zatvaranje formalne maloprodaje jednostavno preusmjeriti potrošnju ka neregulisanim prodavcima

Nijedno ministarstvo nije se bavilo vremenskom apsurdnošću: zakon stupa na snagu odmah po objavljivanju u Službenom listu bez prijelaznog perioda, što znači da preduzeća nemaju apsolutno nikakvo vrijeme da prilagode kadrove, ugovore ili poslovanje

Prijedlog ustavnog amandmana predsjednika Milatovića tretiran je kao zasebna briga, a ne kao ono što jeste: koordinisana politička eskalacija koja signalizira da su izvršna vlast i parlament ujedninjeni u zaobilaženju pravosuđa

Nijedno ministarstvo nije analiziralo preferencije radnika — mnogi zaposleni u maloprodaji, posebno studenti i sezonski radnici, aktivno žele nedeljne smjene zbog premijuma u zaradi ili fleksibilnosti rasporeda

counter_proposal.title: Phased Sunday Rest Law with Tourism Exemptions, Fiscal Safeguards, and Worker Protection Standards
counter_proposal.executive_summary: The AI Government of Montenegro would pursue the same core objective — guaranteed weekly rest for retail workers — but through a properly calibrated framework: mandatory Sunday closure for large retail chains year-round nationwide, with a seasonal tourism-zone exemption system (May–October) for SMEs and tourism-facing retail, mandatory 50% Sunday wage premiums for exempted workers, a pharmacy duty-roster system, and abandonment of the constitutional amendment in favor of flexible statutory protection subject to an 18-month evidence-based review. Critically, the law would have been adopted through regular parliamentary procedure with a full regulatory impact assessment and stakeholder consultation, not an extraordinary session.
counter_proposal.detailed_proposal:
The unified counter-proposal preserves the unanimous parliament's legitimate social objective — protecting retail workers from exploitative seven-day scheduling — while addressing the serious economic, procedural, healthcare, and rule-of-law deficiencies identified across all seven ministries.

**Core Framework: Tiered Sunday Rest.** The backbone of the proposal draws from the Ministry of Economy's tiered model, reinforced by the Ministry of Tourism's seasonal exemption structure. Large retail operations (50+ employees) would observe mandatory Sunday closure year-round nationwide. This targets the businesses most associated with worker exploitation while sparing SMEs and micro-enterprises that are disproportionately harmed by blanket closures. All other retail establishments would observe Sunday closure from November through April, but would be eligible for exemption in designated Tourism Activity Zones from May 1 through October 31. This directly addresses the Ministry of Tourism's central concern: Montenegro's tourism sector generates approximately 25-40% of GDP, Sunday is one of the highest-revenue days in coastal towns, and cruise arrivals in Kotor frequently fall on Sundays. A blanket closure without seasonal exemptions would damage competitiveness against Croatia, Albania, and Greece — all of which maintain flexible Sunday trading in tourist areas.

**Tourism Activity Zones.** Drawing on the Ministry of Tourism's proposal, the Government would designate Tourism Activity Zones by decree, covering coastal municipalities (Budva, Kotor, Tivat, Herceg Novi, Ulcinj, Bar), national park gateway towns (Žabljak, Kolašin), and UNESCO-adjacent areas (Cetinje). Municipal tourism boards would apply annually for zone designation, ensuring local accountability. This mirrors Croatia's Trade Act exemption model and Germany's Ladenschlussgesetz tourist-area provisions.

**Worker Protection in Exempted Zones.** The Ministry of Finance and Ministry of Tourism both converge on the principle that Sunday work, where permitted, must carry a mandatory wage premium. Workers in exempted zones who work Sundays would receive a minimum 50% wage premium and a guaranteed compensatory rest day within the same week. This achieves the social protection objective through economic incentive rather than blanket prohibition, ensuring seasonal workers — approximately 25,000-30,000 people who depend on the May-October window for the bulk of their annual income — are not harmed by reduced earning capacity.

**Pharmacy and Healthcare Access.** The Ministry of Health's counter-proposal is adopted almost in full as a non-negotiable component. A Pharmacy Sunday Duty Regulation would be adopted simultaneously with the trade law, establishing mandatory duty pharmacies: at least one per municipality, with 3-4 in Podgorica and 2 in Nikšić. The RFZO would maintain a real-time duty pharmacy registry (web portal, call center, SMS). Medical supply stores serving chronic disease patients would also be exempted. This draws directly on Croatia's 'dežurne ljekarne' system and addresses a genuine patient safety gap, particularly in rural municipalities with single-pharmacy coverage.

**Security and Border Operations.** Per the Ministry of Interior's recommendations, fuel stations near border crossings (Božaj, Dobrakovo, Debeli Brijeg), airport and port retail, and emergency supply stores would be explicitly exempted through implementing bylaws developed in consultation with the Border Police Directorate. Enforcement responsibility would rest exclusively with the Market Inspectorate, with police involvement limited to public order situations — preventing mission creep onto already-stretched Uprava policije resources.

**Legislative Process Reform.** The Ministry of Justice and Ministry of EU Integration raise the most fundamental objection: not to what the law does, but how it was done. An extraordinary session for a non-emergency social policy measure, with less than three weeks from proposal to adoption, no regulatory impact assessment, no public consultation, and a 62-0 vote that suggests insufficient deliberative scrutiny, is inconsistent with rule-of-law standards the European Commission monitors under Chapter 23. The unified counter-proposal would have pursued adoption through regular parliamentary procedure with full committee review, public hearings, and a commissioned RIA analyzing effects on retail employment, tourism revenue, SME viability, consumer access, and VAT collection. This adds 60-90 days to the timeline — a modest delay overwhelmingly justified by the institutional credibility gained with the European Commission.

**Abandonment of the Constitutional Amendment.** Every ministry that addressed the constitutional proposal — Justice, Finance, Economy, Tourism, and EU Integration — opposed it. This is the strongest consensus across the entire cabinet. No EU member state has constitutionalized Sunday rest for retail workers in this manner. The Venice Commission has consistently advised against over-constitutionalization of matters better left to ordinary legislation. Constitutional entrenchment would eliminate future policy flexibility needed for EU accession negotiations (particularly regarding the Services Directive 2006/123/EC), make economic correction virtually impossible during downturns, and risk politicizing the Constitutional Court's docket with labor-policy disputes. Sunday rest is adequately and appropriately protected at the statutory level.

**Anti-Discrimination Safeguard.** The Ministry of Justice uniquely identified a religious freedom dimension: mandating Sunday specifically as the rest day has Christian connotations that could disadvantage workers of other faiths. The unified proposal includes a reasonable accommodation clause allowing individual workers to request an alternative weekly rest day on religious or personal grounds, consistent with EU anti-discrimination principles.

**Environmental Co-Benefits.** The Ministry of Environment's 'Green Sunday' proposals are incorporated as voluntary municipal initiatives rather than mandatory requirements: car-free urban zones, enhanced public green space programming, and reduced public transport fares on Sundays. Municipalities would also be required to assess and adapt waste collection schedules to account for shifted shopping patterns, particularly Saturday spikes.

**Student and Education Protections.** The Ministry of Education's proposals are integrated through two mechanisms: (1) explicit protection of education-sector Sunday activities (university exams, library operations, research facilities) under the public interest exception framework, and (2) coordination with VET institutions to adjust practical training schedules in retail settings without reducing total training hours. The proposed Student Employment Code (maximum 15 hours/week for secondary, 20 for university students) is flagged for separate legislation rather than incorporation into this law, to avoid scope creep.

**Monitoring and Review.** A mandatory 18-month review clause would require the Government to publish a comprehensive impact assessment covering: VAT revenue effects, retail employment changes, tourism spending patterns, informal economy indicators, pharmacy access complaints, emergency department visit patterns, and seasonal worker income data. Parliament would reconfirm or amend the law based on this evidence. This replaces the constitutional amendment's permanence with an evidence-driven, adaptive approach.

risks_and_tradeoffs: Political risk: The original law passed 62-0, indicating overwhelming political consensus for a blanket approach. Proposing a more nuanced framework may face resistance as appearing to weaken worker protections, despite achieving the same substantive objective through better-calibrated means

Presidential friction: Formally opposing the constitutional amendment directly challenges President Milatović's initiative, creating potential tension between the Government and the presidency — a recurring dynamic in Montenegro's semi-presidential system

Delay risk: The 6-month implementation timeline means the law would not take effect until approximately August-September 2026, meaning the first full tourism season (2027) would be the real test. Workers would not receive Sunday protection until then, creating a gap the original law avoided

Tourism exemption scope creep: Once exemptions exist, political and business pressure to expand them could gradually hollow out the Sunday rest principle. The annual municipal application process is designed to contain this but requires disciplinary enforcement

Enforcement complexity: A tiered system with seasonal exemptions is inherently more complex to enforce than a blanket ban. The Market Inspectorate's capacity to monitor compliance across different enterprise sizes, zones, and seasons is uncertain

Wage premium compliance: The 50% Sunday premium depends on effective labor inspection, which is historically weak in Montenegro, particularly for seasonal workers on informal or semi-formal contracts. Without enforcement, the premium becomes a paper right

Partial environmental benefits lost: By keeping tourism-zone retail open on Sundays during peak season, the marginal environmental benefits (reduced transport, energy consumption) identified by the Ministry of Environment are diminished in the areas with the highest activity

Compromise satisfies no one fully: The Ministry of Economy and Tourism would prefer even broader exemptions; the original law's proponents would prefer no exemptions. This framework occupies defensible middle ground but may lack a passionate political constituency
counter_proposal.title_mne: Fazni Zakon o Nedeljnom Odmoru sa Izuzecima za Turizam, Fiskalnim Zaštitama i Standardima Zaštite Radnika
counter_proposal.executive_summary_mne: AI Vlada Crne Gore bi se rukovodila istim ključnim ciljem — garantovanim sedmičnim odmorom za radnike u maloprodaji — ali kroz pravilno kalibrisani okvir: obavezno nedeljno zatvaranje velikih maloprodajnih lanaca tokom cijele godine na teritoriji cijele države, sa sistemom sezonskih izuzeća za turističke zone (maj–oktobar) za MSP i maloprodaju orijentisanu ka turizmu, obaveznim nedeljnim uvećanjem plate od 50% za radnike obuhvaćene izuzecima, sistemom dežurnih apoteka, te odustajanjem od ustavnog amandmana u korist fleksibilne zakonske zaštite podložne reviziji zasnovanoj na dokazima nakon 18 mjeseci. Od ključne važnosti je to što bi zakon bio usvojen redovnom parlamentarnom procedurom uz punu procjenu regulatornog uticaja i konsultacije sa zainteresovanim stranama, a ne vanrednom sjednicom.
counter_proposal.detailed_proposal_mne:
Objedinjeni kontra-prijedlog čuva legitimni socijalni cilj jednoglasnog parlamenta — zaštitu radnika u maloprodaji od eksploatatorskog sedmodnevnog raspoređivanja — uz istovremeno otklanjanje ozbiljnih ekonomskih, proceduralnih, zdravstvenih nedostataka i nedostataka u pogledu vladavine prava, identifikovanih u svih sedam ministarstava.

**Osnovni okvir: Stepenovani nedeljni odmor.** Okosnica prijedloga crpi iz stenovitog modela Ministarstva ekonomije, ojačanog strukturom sezonskih izuzeća Ministarstva turizma. Velike maloprodajne radnje (50+ zaposlenih) primjenjivale bi obavezno nedeljno zatvaranje tokom cijele godine na teritoriji cijele države. Ovo cilja na preduzeća koja se najčešće dovode u vezu s eksploatacijom radnika, istovremeno štiteći MSP i mikro-preduzeća koja su nesrazmjerno pogođena generalnim zatvaranjem. Sve ostale maloprodajne radnje primjenjivale bi nedeljno zatvaranje od novembra do aprila, ali bi bile podobne za izuzeće u određenim Zonama turističke aktivnosti od 1. maja do 31. oktobra. Ovo direktno adresira centralnu brigu Ministarstva turizma: turistički sektor Crne Gore generiše oko 25–40% BDP-a, nedjelja je jedan od dana s najvećim prihodom u primorskim gradovima, a kruzeri u Kotoru često pristaju nedjeljom. Opšte zatvaranje bez sezonskih izuzeća narušilo bi konkurentnost u odnosu na Hrvatsku, Albaniju i Grčku — koje sve održavaju fleksibilnu nedeljnu trgovinu u turističkim oblastima.

**Zone turističke aktivnosti.** Oslanjajući se na prijedlog Ministarstva turizma, Vlada bi uredbom označila Zone turističke aktivnosti, obuhvatajući primorske opštine (Budva, Kotor, Tivat, Herceg Novi, Ulcinj, Bar), gradove na ulazima u nacionalne parkove (Žabljak, Kolašin) i područja u blizini UNESCO lokaliteta (Cetinje). Opštinska turistička vijeća podnošila bi godišnje zahtjeve za određivanje zone, čime se osigurava lokalna odgovornost. Ovo odražava model izuzeća Zakona o trgovini Hrvatske i odredbe o turističkim područjima njemačkog Ladenschlussgesetz-a.

**Zaštita radnika u zonama izuzeća.** Ministarstvo finansija i Ministarstvo turizma slažu se u načelu da nedeljni rad, tamo gdje je dozvoljen, mora nositi obavezno uvećanje plate. Radnici u zonama izuzeća koji rade nedjeljom dobijali bi minimalno 50% uvećanje plate i garantovani kompenzatorni odmor unutar iste sedmice. Time se postiže cilj socijalne zaštite putem ekonomskog podsticaja, a ne generalnom zabranom, čime se osigurava da sezonski radnici — oko 25.000–30.000 ljudi koji zavise od prozora maj–oktobar za većinu godišnjeg prihoda — nisu oštećeni smanjenim mogućnostima zarade.

**Pristup apotekama i zdravstvenoj zaštiti.** Kontra-prijedlog Ministarstva zdravlja usvojen je gotovo u cijelosti kao nezaobilazna komponenta. Uredba o nedeljnom dežurstvu apoteka usvojena bi bila istovremeno sa zakonom o trgovini, uspostavljajući obavezne dežurne apoteke: najmanje jednu po opštini, s 3–4 u Podgorici i 2 u Nikšiću. RFZO bi vodio registar dežurnih apoteka u realnom vremenu (web portal, pozivni centar, SMS). Radnje s medicinskim potrepštinama za pacijente s hroničnim bolestima bile bi takođe izuzete. Ovo se direktno oslanja na hrvatski sistem 'dežurnih ljekarni' i adresira stvaran jaz u bezbjednosti pacijenata, naročito u ruralnim opštinama s jedinom apotekom.

**Bezbjednost i granične operacije.** U skladu s preporukama Ministarstva unutrašnjih poslova, benzinske pumpe u blizini graničnih prelaza (Božaj, Dobrakovo, Debeli Brijeg), maloprodajni objekti na aerodromima i lukama te prodavnice za hitne slučajeve bili bi eksplicitno izuzeti podzakonskim aktima razvijenim u konsultaciji s Upravom granične policije. Nadležnost za sprovođenje bila bi isključivo na Tržišnoj inspekciji, uz angažovanje policije ograničeno na situacije narušavanja javnog reda — čime se sprječava misionarsko širenje na već preopterećene resurse Uprave policije.

**Reforma zakonodavnog procesa.** Ministarstvo pravde i Ministarstvo evropskih integracija iznose najsuštastveniiji prigovor: ne onome što zakon čini, već tome kako je to urađeno. Vanredna sjednica za mjeru socijalne politike koja nije hitna, s manje od tri sedmice od prijedloga do usvajanja, bez procjene regulatornog uticaja, bez javnih konsultacija i glasanjem 62-0 koje ukazuje na nedovoljnu deliberativnu provjeru, nije u skladu sa standardima vladavine prava koje Evropska komisija prati u okviru Poglavlja 23. Objedinjeni kontra-prijedlog predvidio bi usvajanje redovnom parlamentarnom procedurom uz potpuni pregled u odboru, javna saslušanja i naručenu PRI koja analizira efekte na zaposlenost u maloprodaji, prihode od turizma, životnu sposobnost MSP-a, pristup potrošača i naplatu PDV-a. Ovo dodaje 60–90 dana na vremenski okvir — skroman odgod koji je apsolutno opravdan institucionalnim kredibilitetom stečenim pred Evropskom komisijom.

**Odustajanje od ustavnog amandmana.** Svako ministarstvo koje se bavilo ustavnim prijedlogom — Pravde, Finansija, Ekonomije, Turizma i Evropskih integracija — protivilo mu se. Ovo je najsnažniji konsenzus u čitavom kabinetu. Nijedna zemlja članica EU nije na ovaj način konstitucionalizovala nedeljni odmor za radnike u maloprodaji. Venecijanska komisija dosljednom savjetuje protiv prekomjerne konstitucionalizacije pitanja koja je bolje ostaviti redovnom zakonodavstvu. Ustavno utvrđivanje eliminisalo bi buduću fleksibilnost politike potrebnu za pregovore o pristupanju EU (naročito u pogledu Direktive o uslugama 2006/123/EC), učinilo bi ekonomsku korekciju gotovo nemogućom u periodima recesije i rizikuje da politizuje ulogu Ustavnog suda sporovima o radnoj politici. Nedeljni odmor adekvatno je i prikladno zaštićen na zakonskom nivou.

**Zaštita od diskriminacije.** Ministarstvo pravde jedinstveno je identifikovalo dimenziju vjerske slobode: obavezno određivanje upravo nedjelje kao dana odmora ima hrišćanske konotacije koje bi mogle dovesti u neravnopravan položaj radnike drugih vjera. Objedinjeni prijedlog uključuje klauzulu o razumnoj prilagodbi kojom se pojedinim radnicima omogućava da zahtijevaju alternativni sedmični odmor iz vjerskih ili ličnih razloga, u skladu s EU principima antidiskriminacije.

**Ekološke ko-koristi.** Prijedlozi 'Zelene nedjelje' Ministarstva ekologije integrisani su kao dobrovoljne opštinske inicijative, a ne obavezni zahtjevi: zone bez automobila u urbanim sredinama, unaprijeđeno programiranje javnih zelenih površina i snižene cijene karata javnog prevoza nedjeljom. Od opština bi se takođe zahtijevalo da procijene i prilagode rasporede sakupljanja otpada kako bi uzele u obzir promijenjene obrasce kupovine, naročito subotnje skokove.

**Zaštita studenata i obrazovanja.** Prijedlozi Ministarstva prosvjete integrisani su putem dva mehanizma: (1) eksplicitnom zaštitom nedeljnih aktivnosti obrazovnog sektora (univerzitetski ispiti, rad biblioteka, istraživačke ustanove) u okviru izuzeća od javnog interesa, i (2) koordinacijom sa ustanovama strukovnog obrazovanja radi prilagođavanja rasporeda praktične obuke u maloprodajnim okruženjima bez smanjenja ukupnog broja sati obuke. Predloženi Kodeks zapošljavanja studenata (maksimalno 15 sati/sedmično za učenike srednje škole, 20 za studente) predložen je za zasebno zakonodavstvo, a ne za ugradnju u ovaj zakon, kako bi se izbjeglo proširivanje opsega.

**Praćenje i revizija.** Obavezna klauzula o reviziji nakon 18 mjeseci zahtijevala bi od Vlade da objavi sveobuhvatnu procjenu uticaja koja obuhvata: efekte na prihode od PDV-a, promjene u zaposlenosti u maloprodaji, obrasce turističke potrošnje, pokazatelje sive ekonomije, pritužbe u vezi s pristupom apotekama, obrasce posjeta hitnoj službi i podatke o prihodima sezonskih radnika. Parlament bi na osnovu ovih dokaza potvrdio ili izmijenio zakon. Ovim se ustavna trajna zaštita zamjenjuje pristupom zasnovanim na dokazima i prilagodljivim rješenjima.

implementation_steps_mne: Korak 1 (Sedmice 1–4): Naručiti i objaviti potpunu procjenu regulatornog uticaja koja analizira efekte na prihode od PDV-a, zaposlenost u maloprodaji, turističku potrošnju, životnu sposobnost MSP-a i pristup potrošača

Korak 2 (Sedmice 1–4, paralelno): Sprovesti strukturisane konsultacije sa zainteresovanim stranama s Privrednom komorom, Unijom poslodavaca, Savezom sindikata, Farmaceutskom komorom, udruženjima potrošača i opštinskim turističkim vijećima

Korak 3 (Sedmice 4–8): Izraditi i unijeti izmijenjeni zakon kroz redovni pregled parlamentarnog odbora i javna saslušanja, ugrađujući okvir stepenovanog zatvaranja, izuzeća za turističke zone, zahtjeve za uvećanje plate i klauzulu o zaštiti od diskriminacije

Korak 4 (Sedmice 4–6, paralelno): Usvojiti Uredbu o nedeljnom dežurstvu apoteka ministarskim podzakonskim aktom, uspostavljajući rasporede dežurnih apoteka u svakoj opštini i registar RFZO u realnom vremenu
Korak 5 (Sedmice 4–6, paralelno): Usvojiti podzakonski akt o izuzeću maloprodaje ključne za bezbjednost u konsultaciji s Ministarstvom unutrašnjih poslova i Upravom granične policije
Korak 6 (Sedmice 8–10): Parlamentarno usvajanje redovnom procedurom uz evidentiranu deliberaciju odbora
Korak 7 (Sedmice 10–12): Vlada uredbom određuje početne Zone turističke aktivnosti na osnovu opštinskih zahtjeva i postojećih podataka o turističkoj klasifikaciji

Korak 8 (Sedmice 10–12, paralelno): Izdati operativne smjernice Tržišnoj inspekciji o nadležnostima za sprovođenje, s jasnim protokolima koji ograničavaju policijsku eskalaciju isključivo na situacije narušavanja javnog reda
Korak 9 (Sedmice 12–14): Zvanično obavijestiti Predsjednički kabinet o protivljenju Vlade ustavnom amandmanu, tražeći povlačenje ili odlaganje do pribavljanja mišljenja Venecijanske komisije
Korak 10 (Sedmica 24 / 6 mjeseci): Zakon stupa na snagu sa svim provedbenim propisima na snazi, prije jesenje sezone 2026. godine
Korak 11 (Mjeseci 6–18): Kontinuirano praćenje fiskalnih, zaposlenostnih, turističkih, zdravstveno-pristupnih i pokazatelja sive ekonomije
Korak 12 (Mjesec 18): Objaviti sveobuhvatnu procjenu uticaja i dostaviti je Parlamentu radi potvrđivanja ili izmjene na osnovu dokaza
risks_and_tradeoffs_mne: Politički rizik: Originalni zakon usvojen je glasanjem 62-0, što ukazuje na premoćan politički konsenzus za generalni pristup. Predlaganje preciznijeg okvira može naići na otpor kao čin slabljenja zaštite radnika, uprkos postizanju istog suštinskog cilja boljim sredstvima

Tenzije s predsjednikom: Formalno protivljenje ustavnom amandmanu direktno osporava inicijativu predsjednika Milatovića, stvarajući potencijalnu napetost između Vlade i predsjedništva — povremenu dinamiku u crnogorskom polupredsjedničkom sistemu

Rizik od odgode: Rok za primjenu od 6 mjeseci znači da zakon ne bi stupio na snagu do otprilike avgusta–septembra 2026. godine, što znači da bi prva puna turistička sezona (2027) bila pravi test. Radnici ne bi primali nedeljnu zaštitu do tada, stvarajući jaz koji je originalni zakon izbjegao

Proširivanje opsega izuzeća za turizam: Kada izuzeća postoje, politički i poslovni pritisak za njihovo proširenje mogao bi postepeno potkopati princip nedeljnog odmora. Godišnji proces opštinskog podnošenja zahtjeva osmišljen je da to ograniči, ali zahtijeva disciplinovano sprovođenje

Složenost sprovođenja: Stepenovani sistem sa sezonskim izuzecima inherentno je složeniji za sprovođenje od generalne zabrane. Kapacitet Tržišne inspekcije za praćenje usklađenosti u različitim veličinama preduzeća, zonama i sezonama je neizvjestan

Usklađenost s uvećanjem plate: 50% nedeljnog uvećanja zavisi od djelotvornog rada inspekcije rada, koja je istorijski slaba u Crnoj Gori, naročito za sezonske radnike na neformalnim ili poluformannim ugovorima. Bez sprovođenja, uvećanje ostaje puko pravo na papiru

Izgubak dijela ekoloških koristi: Zadržavanjem maloprodaje u turističkim zonama otvorenom nedjeljom u toku sezone, granične ekološke koristi (smanjenje saobraćaja, potrošnje energije) koje je identifikovalo Ministarstvo ekologije umanjene su u oblastima s najvećom aktivnošću

Kompromis ne zadovoljava u potpunosti nikog: Ministarstvo ekonomije i turizma preferiralo bi još šira izuzeća; zagovornici originalnog zakona preferirali bi nikakva izuzeća. Ovaj okvir zauzima odbranjivo srednje tlo, ali mu možda nedostaje strasna politička podrška
